Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: The Development and Evaluation of an Intelligent Diabetes Self-Management Tool
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to develop an intelligent self-management tool for the 25 million diabetes patients in the US and the 200 million diabetes patients in the world. The proposed study is consonant with the vision of ?learning health system? from the Institute of Medicine in which appropriate interfaces should be provided to engage individuals in population health monitoring and to optimize chronic disease care and control. The proposed technology (Diabetes Self-Management Dashboard) will be applicable across platforms (i.e., mobile devices and personal computers), and will incorporate novel methods that mitigate the technical limitations of existing tools. The proposed project covers the development and evaluation of the technology. Although diabetes was chosen as the research case, the project is transferable to other chronic conditions that may benefit from an intelligent self-management application.

The proposed project accentuates the inter-relationship among intelligent health IT interventions, theoretical psycho-behavioral determinants, and clinical outcome from self-care. The proposition is that through this multifaceted perspective, we may better delineate the essences in diabetes self-management, and then offer optimized social-technical support accordingly. The team intends to overcome several limitations of existing self-management tools: 1) ignoring the potential of mobile devices in self-care, 2) failing to translate self-monitoring data to patient-interpretable implications, and 3) lacking tailored educational materials and actionable recommendations. The specific technical innovations include: 1) health status monitoring and trend projection, 2) assessment and prediction of risks for major events (e.g., stroke, heart attack, and hospitalization), 3) recommendation of personalized educational materials, and 4) several social functionalities. Along with the technical innovations, we formulate comprehensive evaluation plans that critically assess the usability of the technology (via System Usability Scale and semi-structured interviews), the effectiveness of the technology (via within-subjects and between-groups design of field experiments), and the proposed theoretical model and research hypotheses (via structural equation modeling). The project is expected to result into an advanced and commecializable system is expected t is powered by scientific algorithms and motivated by relevant health behavioral theories, with systematic assessment on its usability and effectiveness.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Diabetes Mellitus is one of the leading causes of death in the United States. It is a serious, chronic condition that, if left unchecked, can lead to organ failure, loss of limbs, and many other serious complications. Diabetes is a condition in which the body produces little or no insulin resulting in glucose build-up in the body. The effects of diabetes can be lessened with a healthy lifestyle, but success requires extensive and continuous health management and is often stressful for the diabetics as well as their family members and caregivers. Due to this nature of the disease, several organizations such as the American Diabetes Association (ADA) and the International Federation of Diabetes are using the Internet to educate people about diabetes self-management and provide online support via community chats. However, most existing online diabetes self-management tools have limitations. Most do not provide any personalized healthcare recommendations based on an individual’s current medical state and are often limited in their functionality.

Caduceus Intelligence Corporation (a spin-off of the University of Arizona) in association with the Artificial Intelligence Lab at the University of Arizona and the National Taiwan University, has developed a website called DiabeticLink - a one-stop online solution for improving diabetes self-management (fully utilizable on both mobile devices and personal computers). It incorporates novel methods for health status monitoring and trend projection, assessment and prediction of risks for major events (e.g., stroke, heart attack, and hospitalization), recommendation of personalized education materials, and several social functionalities. 

The Health Resources Module on DiabeticLink collects diabetes-relevant information from credible online sources in the form of news articles, blogs, videos and tweets. This resource is very helpful for those (diabetics and family members/caregivers) who need to find specific diabetes-related information online. People looking for health monitoring tools can use the Tracking Moduleon the DiabeticLink website. This module allows tracking of 8 different health parameters (blood pressure, blood glucose, food intake, activity, insulin and more). Even non-diabetics can use this feature to track their health and view, for example, the impact of the food they eat upon their weight or upon the level of activity they perform. Advanced visualization of tracking data also helps users make meaningful inferences about their health. All tracking reports generated are downloadable in a PDF/Excel format making it easier for users to share health data with physicians. Diabetics and others who are at a risk of heart disease or stroke can use the Risk Engine Module to predict their risk of hospitalization, CVD (cardiovascular disease) or stroke by evaluating their health parameters including cholesterol levels, age, gender, etc. The risk engine will also provide actionable recommendations to reduce this risk. 

Diabetics or caregivers/family members of diabetics often seek support from others in similar situations. For this purpose DiabeticLink has built an onlineSocial Community Module where everyone can come together to share their experiences without concern for privacy issues. One can create a profile, make friends, and support others like themselves to develop a healthier lifestyle.

To understand DiabeticLink’s usefulness and consider the feasibility of further development, we evaluated the website by recruiting 30 subjects including type 1 and type 2 diabetics, caregivers, nurses and physicians. As a part of the user study (ap...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Diabetes Mellitus is one of the leading causes of death in the United States. It is a serious, chronic condition that, if left unchecked, can lead to organ failure, loss of limbs, and many other serious complications. Diabetes is a condition in which the body produces little or no insulin resulting in glucose build-up in the body. The effects of diabetes can be lessened with a healthy lifestyle, but success requires extensive and continuous health management and is often stressful for the diabetics as well as their family members and caregivers. Due to this nature of the disease, several organizations such as the American Diabetes Association (ADA) and the International Federation of Diabetes are using the Internet to educate people about diabetes self-management and provide online support via community chats. However, most existing online diabetes self-management tools have limitations. Most do not provide any personalized healthcare recommendations based on an individualÆs current medical state and are often limited in their functionality. Caduceus Intelligence Corporation (a spin-off of the University of Arizona) in association with the Artificial Intelligence Lab at the University of Arizona and the National Taiwan University, has developed a website called DiabeticLink - a one-stop online solution for improving diabetes self-management (fully utilizable on both mobile devices and personal computers). It incorporates novel methods for health status monitoring and trend projection, assessment and prediction of risks for major events (e.g., stroke, heart attack, and hospitalization), recommendation of personalized education materials, and several social functionalities. The Health Resources Module on DiabeticLink collects diabetes-relevant information from credible online sources in the form of news articles, blogs, videos and tweets. This resource is very helpful for those (diabetics and family members/caregivers) who need to find specific diabetes-related information online. People looking for health monitoring tools can use the Tracking Moduleon the DiabeticLink website. This module allows tracking of 8 different health parameters (blood pressure, blood glucose, food intake, activity, insulin and more). Even non-diabetics can use this feature to track their health and view, for example, the impact of the food they eat upon their weight or upon the level of activity they perform. Advanced visualization of tracking data also helps users make meaningful inferences about their health. All tracking reports generated are downloadable in a PDF/Excel format making it easier for users to share health data with physicians. Diabetics and others who are at a risk of heart disease or stroke can use the Risk Engine Module to predict their risk of hospitalization, CVD (cardiovascular disease) or stroke by evaluating their health parameters including cholesterol levels, age, gender, etc. The risk engine will also provide actionable recommendations to reduce this risk. Diabetics or caregivers/family members of diabetics often seek support from others in similar situations. For this purpose DiabeticLink has built an onlineSocial Community Module where everyone can come together to share their experiences without concern for privacy issues. One can create a profile, make friends, and support others like themselves to develop a healthier lifestyle. To understand DiabeticLinkÆs usefulness and consider the feasibility of further development, we evaluated the website by recruiting 30 subjects including type 1 and type 2 diabetics, caregivers, nurses and physicians. As a part of the user study (approved by our Institutional Review Board), we conducted one-on-one interviews and surveys with all participants. All users were asked to use the system and provide feedback as they filtered through each module on the website. User responses provided very useful feedback for continued system improvement.
